channel.title: Data Management on StatsNotebook - Simple. Powerful. Reproducible.
channel.description: Recent content in Data Management on StatsNotebook - Simple. Powerful. Reproducible.

item.title: Reshaping data
item.description: Follow our Facebook page or our developer’s Twitter for more tutorials and future updates This tutorial will provide step-by-step guide on reshaping the data from Wide to Long Long to Wide Wide to Long We will use the built-in Human Development Index dataset in this example. This dataset can be loaded into StatsNotebook using instruction here. This is a data from the United Nations Development Programmes (UNDP). This dataset contains the following variables

item.title: Compute variables
item.description: Follow our Facebook page or our developer’s Twitter for more tutorials and future updates StatsNotebook provides a simple menu for creating new variables. We will give two examples below to demonstrate using StatsNotebook to compute new variables. Log transformation Creating a quadratic term In these two examples, we will use the built-in Personality dataset. This dataset can be loaded into StatsNotebook using instruction here or can be downloaded from here.

item.title: Load Example Data
item.description: Follow our Facebook page or our developer’s Twitter for more tutorials and future updates StatsNotebook comes with a rich data library for learning statistics. To load an example dataset, Click the Menu icon at the top Click “Open” Select “Example Data” from the menu Click on the example data we want to load. Follow our Facebook page or our developer’s Twitter for more tutorials and future updates

item.title: Set reference for categorical variables
item.description: Follow our Facebook page or our developer’s Twitter for more tutorials and future updates For categorical variable, it is important to set a “reference” category in many analyses. For example, for the variable Sex in our regression analysis tutorial, the default reference is Female. The coefficient of SexMale from the regression represents the effect of male relative to female. In this case, the coefficient -0.87 means that the depression score (the dependent variable in that analysis) for male is 0.

item.title: Variable types in R and StatsNotebook
item.description: Follow our Facebook page or our developer’s Twitter for more tutorials and future updates There are four major variable types in StatsNotebook: Categorical, Numeric, Date and Character. By default, when data is loaded into StatsNotebook, the variables are either Numeric or Character variables. Categorical variables Categorical variables are variables that have two or more categories. For example, sex is a categorical variable that we can code into male and female. Another exapmle is color, which we can code into Yellow, Red, Orange, etc.
